segments.text: This literal administrative tug of war began to reach a climax in the spring of 1980.
On more than one occasion,
Those of us who met with Doctor Miller.
Informally after normal working hours.
Tried to.
Persuade him.
To back away from a showdown fight.
All over this point.
And we particularly.
tried to persuade, tried to convince him of the reality that Dr Hubert would be retiring in a couple of years, and that if he played his administrative cards carefully,
He would succeed Hubert as chancellor, and then he could have the oversight that he desired.
I certainly remember on one occasion Dr. Miller's agreeing with our point completely.
And he promised to.
Quote back off.
Quote.
Apparently he.
Did not.
Cease his contention.
And the matter.
Came.
To a climax.
in late in June 1980.
The board came to meet on the campus just after
Joe and I, with our kids and a truckload of belongings, went on our way to the new task at the University of Texas at El Paso.
That series of events for me had begun back in the previous winter.
Sometime late in 1979,
I received an inquiry regarding whether or not I would be willing to be considered for the presidency at North Texas State, which at that time seemed like a very nice step forward for me.
It seemed rather quick that I was one of the interviewees and went before the Board of Regents of what was then NTSU.
Their first question will always be memorable.
because one of the group asked how long I thought it would take me if they selected me as their new chief executive officer to gain admission for the North Texas Eagles into the Southwest Conference.
My recollection is that I told them I did not think God would live that long.
And with a frown, they asked why.
And I tried to explain my feeling, my opinion that neither SMU nor TCU was at all willing to accept another Metroplex area institution as their equal.
And that similarly, the four public institutions, Texas public institutions already in the SWC, Texas A&M, Texas Tech, the University of Texas at Austin, and Texas Tech,
Would not.
See much advantage.
To elevating.
That green and white team.
To their status.
Before they.
Announced their decision.
Don Walker, the chancellor of the University of Texas system, called me to ask if I would be willing to be interviewed for the presidency at the University of Texas at El Paso.
I expressed my gratitude and feeling of being flattered
But told him that I thought it probably was not.
Appropriate.
To allow my name to be.
Placed in the UTEP pot.
Since I was a finalist at North Texas.
His blunt response was.
That the North Texas search had been determined.
Before they went through the formalities.
And that Frank Vandiver
My former dissertation advisor.
At Rice.
Would be the new North Texas president.
Dash a prediction.
Which turned out to be very accurate.
Paragraph.
Thus Chancellor Walker.
Call me a few days after the North Texas.
Presidential search ended.

and asked if I would be considered, and I submitted all of the appropriate materials and began to learn as much as possible about the past of the North and the institution that had begun early in the century as the Texas School of Mines.
Joe and I were pleasantly surprised to be one of the six campus interviewee couples.
Soon I realized that they had a very inclusive goal in their finalists.
because the on-campus visitors included an Hispanic, a female, a black, a non-native-born American, the vice president of academic affairs at UT Arlington.
and yours truly, an employee of Texas A&M, certainly a minority in a UT search.
Paragraph, a backward look at the campus process led me to conclude that all of the
Parties in that effort did their task with skill and grace.
All of the candidates seemed all of the interview groups seemed to be comparatively well informed and honest in their efforts.
And we began to feel that El Paso
would be far more pleasant as a place of residence than we had originally thought.
The next step was to pair the six down to three, a trio of names that would be submitted to the Board of Regents for their review and final decision.
I learned that I had made that trio immediately after a coordinating board meeting in Austin when Ernie Smurton, the Vice Chancellor of the UT System for Academic Affairs, who with his

always energetic and highly capable wife, Joanne, had been a member of the young couples class at the Presbyterian Church in Bryan back in the early 60s when he was the director of the Texas Water Resources Institute.
Another stop in this review came when two of the Bonilla brothers, Corpus Christi natives who were zealous leaders of LULAC,

The League of United Latin American Citizens came to College Station to try to encourage Dr. Miller to give more emphasis at A&M to the recruitment and retention of Hispanics, especially in the student body.
Dr. Miller asked me to assist these two visitors.
And as their visit concluded with lunch at the president's house, Jarvis whispered in my ear to accompany them to their car parked over near the Koch building.
As we made that
walk of approximately four blocks.
Tony chatted with vigor all the way while his brother, Ruben, R-E-U-B-E-N, was silent and intensely observant.
As we reached their car and I opened the door for them, Ruben suddenly quickly turned to me and asked if I was going to be the new president at UTEP.
I responded that I suspected they would not select me.
He asked why, and I told him since I was an Anglo, I assumed that they would pick Dr. Hernandez, a native
of New Mexico and the Dean of Engineering at New Mexico State, whose wife was a professor of English at UTEP.
He firmly disagreed with me and said, Hernandez does not have a chance.
When I asked why, he
told me that he and his fellow Hispanics could accept the fact that I, as an Anglo, was not fluent in Spanish, but that if my name was Hernandez and I did not speak Spanish, that was truly
put truly unacceptable in quotation marks.
Thus, the three names, the board interviewed three of us.
As I recall, the
interim president at Colorado State, the academic vice president at UT Arlington, and myself.
Dr. Smurton called me to make arrangements for that session, which was scheduled in Houston
at the cancer center.
The first word of the name I cannot recall at this point.
Each of us would be interviewed by the board in executive session after they had completed all of their other business sometime about midday on Friday.
Further advice was that I should not bring Joe to the session and that perhaps I should eat a sandwich before coming because the session might run beyond the noon hour.
When we arrived, each of the three interviewees was placed in a different room so that we did not see each other on that morning.
I happened to have the honor of being welcomed by the man who had organized that splendid
Cancer Treatment Center back in 1942 and had a delightful conversation with him about the progress of that splendid agency.
I've always thought, paragraph, I've always thought that I was the third in sequential order to go before the board.

which was seated on either side of a comparatively long table with the chairman at the other end so 10 of us at the table with the chancellor sitting alongside the board chairman as they proceeded around the table for the interview which did not consume
much more than a half hour, I realized at its conclusion that each regent asked one question and that their interrogatories not only were very well selected and phrased,
but that they touched the truly vital, each of the truly vital areas that a campus chief executive officer should handle.
Such topic is academic freedom,
institutional breadth and depth, public relations and fundraising, student recruitment and retention, fundraising and development, legislative matters and community relations,
legal realities, and personal health and integrity.
One of the regents, the regent seated immediately to my right, son of one of the founders of the Humble Oil Company,
gave every indication of being totally asleep through most of the session.
Finally, as we had circled the table, the chairman indicated, asked for further questions, then thanked me
and told me that they would be in communication later to let me know their decision.
As I started to get up, the sleepy gentleman shifted in his chair and then directed me as he said,
Sit down boy.
I want to ask you a question.
Then continued.
Well, Texas blood is orange.
Aggie blood is maroon.
Can you change the color of your blood?
Period quote.
Prince paragraph, having never anticipated that truly meaningful and penetrating question.
I paused and then offered as my response.
My feeling of gratitude and pride at having been able to go to Austin College.
as a comparatively reserved, shy boy from a working class family, and that I would always be grateful to that institution for what it had meant to my life.
Then I continued by noting that I had been lucky to be admitted to Rice back in the era when there was no tuition fee
and that the blue and gray would always have a special place in my heart.
Then in 1959, with a pregnant wife and very little money in the bank, A&M gave us a job and we had
been grateful for the 21 years of very meaningful experience there.
And I tried to add that I believed that we could also, would also be very proud and grateful to add the University of Texas at El Paso to the
institutions that were dear to our hearts.
Luckily, Governor Dolph Briscoe's personal physician, who was sitting across from this questioner at the Regent's table, smiled as he said, let me help this young man a moment.
And he told his colleagues that

When he delivered the first child for a young couple and placed the new baby in the parents' arms, they indicated they would never love anything else in their life as much as that child, dash, dash, dash, until he delivered their second child
and placed it in their arms.
At that point, I quickly rose and said, I rest my case and thank you for your courtesy.
As I, paragraph, as I walked away, Dr. Smurden asked me where the board could, where I could be reached by telephone.
And I told him that I was heading back to the Post Oak Mall, to the Galleria, where I had left Jo.
And she was simply going to kill time until I returned.
Since there was an indefinite
Nature to the Regents meeting.
We had agreed that after 1 30 she would check.
Every half hour.
At the bookstore there.
At Walton.
At Walden Bookshop.
And that whenever I got there, I would go.
There and wait for her.
And so he indicated that they would simply, when they, when the board reached his decision, they would call Walden Bookshop hoping to find me there.
Thus, I drove back from the medical center to the Galleria at the corner of Westheimer and Post Oak Road.
and headed for the bookstore.
When I walked in the front door of that establishment, I asked for the location of their telephone.
The clerk, thinking I was asking for a public telephone, quickly responded that they did not have a phone.
In shock, I worried about the fact that I would never might never know what the board had decided.
But then she clarified the matter.
By telling me.
That their in house phone.
Was near the back of the store.
As I walked back.
To that point.
Looking for the phone, I happen to notice a pair of legs that seemed very recognizable extending beyond the counter.
And as I rounded the corner, Jo was there on the floor with the phone in her hands and a bright smile on her face.
And as she looked up at me while talking on the phone, she signaled with her lips, we won.
Quickly, she then told me that she was talking to Ernie Smurton, who had called there to inform us
that I had been selected for the UTEP task.
Thus, on February 29, 1980, leap year day, we hurried back from Houston to Lawyer Street, to 1901 Lawyer.
thinking about a momentous relocation of family, energy, and heartfelt devotion.
On the paragraph on the way back, we briefly discussed
selling the house that we had built with such care and devotion 10 years earlier.
